Your child, if in grades K, 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9, may be given a vision screening during this school year. Every attempt is made to have student vision screening completed within 60 days from the start of the school year. you will receive a referral letter if your child fails the screening. However, even if your child passed, it is important that your child see an eye care specialist once a year.

School vision screening does not evaluate eye health and cannot uncover important vision problems or prescribe treatment. Vision referral information, on children age 8 and under, will be reported to the Utah State Division for the Blind and Visually Impaired as stated in Utah Law 53A-11-203.

Because academic learning is 80% visual, and visual problems are best detected and treated early, a comprehensive eye and vision examination is recommended. Healthy eyes and good vision are essential for success in school.

-When crossing the parking lot, please only do so in the crosswalk

Do you love to doodle? Is art your happy place? Are you a genius at digital design? We want you to create some fantastic art for this year's Mountainville Yearbook! The top Elementary and Middle School entries will be used for this year's Mountainville Yearbook cover.

The deadline for the cover contest is January 21. Work can be turned into the main office or sent digitally to mwallgren@malions.org with "Yearbook Cover Art Contest" in the subject line. Be sure and include the name of the artist with the work.

The theme for this year's Yearbook is "Memories Made."

Entries should be sized to fit on an 8 1/2 x 11 sheet of paper and created with "portrait" orientation (short edges on the top and bottom, longer edges on the sides).
Elementary students should include a lion in their design.
Middle school students should include photography tools like a camera or film in their design.
